WIP: Fix format inconsistencies in the way swift server returns error responses

The error response generation in all the servers inside swift is pretty
much inconsistent. They don't respect the accept header of the request.
In some parts, the accept header isn't passed to the backend server at all.
Some parts, even when the backend server responds with a proper format
response such as JSON, and sets the content-type also accordingly, the proxy
server overwrites it with the standard text/html content-type. Some parts,
we always hard code and return text/plain error response, irrespective of the
content type asked. This patch is a attempt to fix all those incosistencies.
This is a WIP. Need feedback/comments about the direction I'm heading.

subject: Introduce a simple state machine module
commit_message:
Introduce a simple state machine module

States are used in an ad-hoc fashion all over Nova codebase. It's high
time we added some code that will let us define and abstract basic
operations with state changes.

This commit adds 2 classes that will be used to define the state graph,
and a simple way to step through the state graph. For this we use the
"automaton" library, that is already in uses by several other OpenStack
projects for similar purposes.

Class State is holds a state-space and a name of the state, and a list
of states that we could go from it. Each State instance references 0
or more other states within the same state-space as it's next_states
attribute thus creating a directed graph.

Class FSM represents a state machine, and is a slightly customized
version of the automaton FiniteMachine class that when given a
state-space, builds a graph of all known states and it's transitions,
and also exposes a step() method that will either progress the machine
to a new state or raise an error if the transition is not valid for the
given state-space.

Related-blueprint: migration-fix-resource-tracking
Change-Id: Ic3c9dbd4af8fe92499d84d43ca3e48783f3a59de

subject: Add SwiftRingBuild parameter
commit_message:
Add SwiftRingBuild parameter

We want to add the facility to disable Swift ring building on nodes
running Swift.  To do this we add a parameter called SwiftRingBuild.
If this parameter is set to False or F, then the swift element will
not attempt to build the rings.  If this parameter is set to True
(the default) or T then the swift element will build the rings.

We want to allow an operator to turn off ring-building in the case
where new Swift nodes are being added to an existing Swift cluster.
In the absence of any tooling to help with ring management the
operator will have to use the default method of building new rings
to include the new nodes, and distributing the rings to the Swift
nodes - including existing nodes.

There is a corresponding element change, see
https://review.openstack.org/109029

subject: Update dhcp host portbinding on failover
commit_message:
Update dhcp host portbinding on failover

When a dhcp server is moved to new host on failover,
tunnel is not created.

When a dhcp server is moved to new host,
1) network-hostagent binding is updated(properly i.e with new host).
2) dhcp port-hostagent binding is not updated
   ( dhcp port is still bound to old host)
If dhcp port-bound agent is different from the new dhcp agent
(which is now taking care of this dhcp port), neutron plugin won't
 notify the l2pop, and hence tunnel is not created.

As after failover, the new agent is taking care of this dhcp port,
update portbinding with the new host. This will allow neutron plugin
to notify l2pop(which will create tunnel).

Adds an LBAAS driver

This is the start of the LBAAS driver.  If you point [lbaas] config
at the existing akanda appliance image, it should spin up a new instance
on and manage the neutron resource's state according to the akanda resource.

This LB driver expects to be able to push its config to the akanda-appliance
server running in the image, and that server is responsible for translating
what the RUG gives it to something suitable for the LB service installed in
that image.  There will be a corresponding change to akanda-appliance for this.

The drivers port creation callback currently creates a instance port on the
same network as the LB VIP and auths it as an allowed adddress pair. During
config push to the appliance, we include the VIP port in the configs'
interface map so as to bring up the VIP on the right interface. Note this currently
does not instruct the appliance to bring up the actual address we create for it.

This requires a corresponding change to akanda-neutron to enable
the akloadbalancerstatus api extension: http://review.openstack.org/#/c/225370/

subject: Redirect "apt-get install -y" stdin to /dev/null
commit_message:
Redirect "apt-get install -y" stdin to /dev/null

According to debian bug 728775 [1] apt-get by design will consume stdin
(even when not run interactively).

When the run-aio-build.sh script is used as part of a curl-pipe-bash
such as described in the quick start docs [2] apt-get will effectively
halt execution of the script after installing git. The next time the
script is run it will get past the step because git is now installed and
apt-get no longer consumes stdin. In addition to run-aio-build.sh,
bootstrap-aio.sh and bootstrap-ansible.sh call apt-get and so exhibit
the same behaviour when called by run-aio-build.sh when used as part of
a curl-pipe-bash.

In addition to apt-get install -y, apt-get purge -y exhibits the same
behaviour.

The result for the end user is they must run the command multiple times
to get it to work.

Using the bash method to close stdin (0<&- [3]) causes apt-get to print
out "E: Write error - write (14: Bad address)" and fail. The solution is
to explicitly set stdin to nothing, such as "echo '' | apt-get ..." or
"apt-get ... < /dev/null". The latter is chosen for its aesthetics.

yum install -y does not exhibit this behaviour and so does not require
its stdin redirected.

[1] https://bugs.debian.org/cgi-bin/bugreport.cgi?bug=728775
[2] http://docs.openstack.org/developer/openstack-ansible/developer-docs/quickstart-aio.html#running-an-aio-build-in-one-step
[3] http://www.tldp.org/LDP/abs/html/io-redirection.html

Change-Id: I57484590e257956e1d1bc8e10ce8a35207622672
Closes-Bug: 1504546

subject: Removing ceph locking system
commit_message:
Removing ceph locking system

The ceph locking system doesn't work as expected.
When the client loose the connection to ceph, Locks are
not released, so more code need to be added to expire
the lock when it's no more updated and/or break it when
we detect a client that hold the lock is dead.

Instead of this, this change just use tooz as meachnism system.

And a ceph driver will be added to tooz instead. Tooz have
already a tests coverage for drivers, it should be easier to
detect this kind of race.

This change have a migration impact, changing the lock meachism
means all gnocchi daemons must be stopped before upgrading them.

ovs-cleanup-->netns-cleanup-->openvswitch

Instead of a single chain like

neutron-server-->ovs-cleanup-->netns-cleanup-->openvswitch-->

subject: Update dhcp host portbinding on failover
commit_message:
Update dhcp host portbinding on failover

When a dhcp server is moved to new host on failover,
tunnel is not created.

When a dhcp server is moved to new host,
1) network-hostagent binding is updated(properly i.e with new host).
2) dhcp port-hostagent binding is not updated
   ( dhcp port is still bound to old host)
If dhcp port-bound agent is different from the new dhcp agent
(which is now taking care of this dhcp port), neutron plugin won't
 notify the l2pop, and hence tunnel is not created.

As after failover, the new agent is taking care of this dhcp port,
update portbinding with the new host. This will allow neutron plugin
to notify l2pop(which will create tunnel).

Change-Id: Ib7d7dcddee005395af116ccd31a43853332ae317
Closes-bug: #1411163

subject: Policies based properties protection
commit_message:
Policies based properties protection

To leverage rule based properties protection, "property_protection_file"
and "property_protection_rule_format" should be turned on in `cinder.conf`.

`property-protections-policies.conf` should be presented, typically, drop
this file in `/etc/cinder/` directory, sample configuration files are
provided with the source.

If the rule format is defined as `rule`, the rule defined in
`property-protections-policies.conf` will be parsed and appended with rules
defined in the `policy.json`.

One action(create, read, update, delete) one rule, there is no need define
multi-rules for one action since rules is recursive itself. The rule here
will be checked in the rules defined in `policy.json`, all the same with
oslo.policy verification.

Failing the rule check will throw `ReservedProperty` exception, and
properties modification will fail as well.

DocImpact: How to enable properties protection need to be documented.
Partially implements: bp support-modify-volume-image-metadata
Change-Id: I80ba460a0981d80e31f0943c77ca4f368a0066df

subject: Role based properties protection
commit_message:
Role based properties protection

To leverage role based properties protection, "property_protection_file"
and "property_protection_rule_format" should be turned on in `cinder.conf`.

`property-protections.conf` should be presented, typically, drop this file
in `/etc/cinder/` directory, sample configuration files are provided with
the source.

If the rule format is defined as `role`, the roles of the user who triggers
the modification of specific property will be compared with rule defined in
the `property-protections.conf`, if one role of user matched with the
permitted role associated with the property, rule check passed the
verification or else exception: ReservedProperty will be thrown out.

DocImpact: How to enable properties protection need to be documented.

subject: Introduce property utils for parsing protection files
commit_message:
Introduce property utils for parsing protection files

This patch bring in the utils used to parse the property protection
files, such as property-protections.conf.

- template file for role based protections
For example, if the file listed as property_protection_file has:
[prop_a]
create = admin,spl_role

then the corresponding rule after parsing is the tuple like this,
(spl_create_prop, {"create": [admin, spl_role]})

In the list of user roles, @ means all roles and ! means no role,
! and @ are mutually exclusive.

- template file for policies based protections
For example, if the file listed as property-protections-policies.conf
has:
[prop_a]
create = cinder_creator
then the corresponding policy rule appended to the oslo policies
like this,
"prop_a:create": "rule:cinder_creator"

while cinder_creator is defined in policy.json. For example:
"cinder_creator": "role:admin or role:cinder_create_user"

This patch use role based protections template file as the start,
and policy based part will be given with `Policies based
properties protection`.

Partially implements: bp support-modify-volume-image-metadata

Change-Id: I15dbb7c647c57e04947df8cc35669ee0be9c0a24

subject: Add references to SG callbacks to avoid GC
commit_message:
Add references to SG callbacks to avoid GC

ML2 mechanism driver for MidoNet is currently used in both the Liberty
and Kilo environment, and must continue to support both cases.

In Kilo, weakref was used for storing callback methods where they would
get garbage collected, making all callbacks registered unavailable.
This problem was fixed in Liberty with the commit 8959032.

Until post-Liberty when we no longer need to support the mech driver
compatibility with Kilo ML2, add explicit references to the callback
methods so that they are not garbage collected.

Revert this patch when there is no need to support compatibility with
Kilo ML2.
